page.title: 05Local Housing
page.content: Properties in{Castle Cary}tend to be either terraced cottages (or houses) or detached houses. They are built mostly of local ham stone, with recently built properties, e.g. those on the Church Field development at {Ansford,}being built of a re-constituted stone designed to resemble the local stone. There are fewer brick houses, and these are usually terraced. Property in the surrounding villages are again built chiefly from stone and are again mainly terraced or detatched cottages, with a few large detatched stone farmhouses or rectories. Hardly any brick properties are to be found. The most common form of roofing is tile, but there are a few slate and thatched rooves.
